quest_title: If the equations \(a_1x^2 + b_1x + c_1 = 0 \) and \(a_2x^2 + b_2x + c_2 = 0 \) have one root common, then:
explanation_txt:
Given equations are:

\(a_1x^2 + b_1x + c_1 = 0 \\ a_2x^2 + b_2x + c_2 = 0 \)

Let \( \alpha \) be the common root.

Then:

\(a_1 \alpha ^2 + b_1 \alpha + c_1 = 0 \\ a_2 \alpha^2 + b_2 \alpha + c_2 = 0 \)

Let \( \alpha^2 = X \) and \( \alpha = Y \)

\(a_1X + b_1Y + c_1 = 0 \\ a_2X+ b_2Y + c_2 = 0 \)

Using the rule of cross-multiplication:

\( \cfrac{X}{b_1c_2-b_2c_1} = \cfrac{Y}{a_2c_1-a_1c_2} = \cfrac{1}{a_1b_2-b_1a_2} \)

Using \( X = Y^2 \)

\( (b_1c_2 - b_2c_1)(a_1b_2 - b_1a_2) = (a_2c_1 - a_1c_2)^2 \)

It is better to make two equations satisfying condition given in question and check options. For example the equations \(x^2 - 5x + 6 = 0 \) and \(x^2 - 3x + 2 = 0 \) have \(2\) as common root.

explanation_plain_text:
Given equations are:

Let be the common root.

Let and

Using the rule of cross-multiplication:

Using

It is better to make two equations satisfying condition given in question and check options. For example the equations and have as common root.

quest_title: A particle reaches its highest point when it has covered exactly one half of its horizontal range. The corresponding point on the displacement time graph is characterized by
explanation_txt: The graph above is displacement time graph for projectile motion with initial velocity \(u=5m/s\) and angle of projection \(72^{\circ}\). Y axis represents displacement whereas X axis represents time. The dotted point in the graph represents the highest point reached by particle. From the graph, the curve at the dotted point has positive slope with negative curvature.

quest_title: A truck of mass 30,000kg moves up an inclined plane of slope 1 in 100 at a speed of 30 kmph. The power of the truck is (given g = 10 m/s2)
explanation_txt:
As truck is moving on an incline plane therefore only component of weight (mg sin \(\theta\) will oppose the upward motion

Power = \(= \text { force } \times \text { velocity } = m g \sin \theta \times v\)

\(= 30000 \times 10 \times \left( \cfrac { 1 } { 100 } \right) \times \cfrac { 30 \times 5 } { 18 } = 25 k W\)

quest_title: The first excitation potential of given atom is 10.2 eV. Then the ionization potential must be
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{eV}_{e}=\mathrm{E}_{2}-\mathrm{E}_{1}\)
\(10.2 \mathrm{eV}=\mathrm{E}_{2}-\mathrm{E}_{1}\)
This atom is Hydrogen
\(\mathrm{E}_{1}=\mathrm{E}_{\infty}-\mathrm{E}_{1}=0-(-13.6)=13.6 \mathrm{eV}\)

quest_title: The tangent at P, any point on the circle \(x ^ { 2 } + y ^ { 2 } = 4\), meets the coordinate axes in A and B, then
ans3_txt: locus of midpoint of AB is \(x^2+y^2 = x^2y^2 \)
explanation_txt:
Let \( (a,b) \) be any point of \( x^2 + y^2 = 4 \) The tangent is \(ax + by = 4 \)

Thus, the coordinates of A and B are \( A(4/a, 0 ) \) and \( B(0, 4/b) \)

Obviously AB, PA and PB all depend on the point chosen.

midpoint of \( AB \) is \( (2/a , 2/b) = (h,k)\) (Say)

But as \( (a,b) \) is on circle, \(a^2 + b^2 = 4 \)

Or, \( \cfrac{4}{h^2} + \cfrac{4}{k^2} = 4 \)

Or, \( \cfrac{h^2+k^2}{h^2k^2} = 1 \)

Hence the locus is \( x^2 + y^2 = x^2y^2 \)

explanation_txt:
The direction cosines are proportional to \(1,2,-3\).

\( r = \sqrt{1^2+2^2+(-3)^2} = \sqrt{14} \)

So,

\( (l,m,n) = \pm \left( \cfrac{1}{\sqrt{14}}, \cfrac{2}{\sqrt{14}}, \cfrac{-3}{\sqrt{14}} \right) \)

So, option (d) is correct.

quest_title: \[ \int _{a}^{b}\cfrac{\log x}{x} \, dx= \]
explanation_txt:
Let

\[ I=\int _{a}^{b}\cfrac{1}{x} \log x\, dx=(\log x\log x)_{a}^{b} -\int _{a}^{b}\cfrac{1}{x} \log x\, dx \]

\[\Rightarrow 2I=[(\log x)^{2} ]_{a}^{b} \]

\[ \Rightarrow I=\cfrac{1}{2} [(\log b)^{2} -(\log a)^{2} ]\]

\[ \Rightarrow I =\cfrac{1}{2} [(\log b+\log a)(\log b-\log a)] \]

\[ \Rightarrow I =\cfrac{1}{2} \log (ab)\log \left(\cfrac{b}{a} \right).\]

quest_title: If \( \omega \) is a complex cube root of unity, then \(( 1 + \omega ) \left( 1 + \omega ^ { 2 } \right)\left( 1 + \omega ^ { 4 } \right) \left( 1 + \omega ^ { 8 } \right) \dots\) to 2n factors =
explanation_txt:
Let \( n =1 \)

Then \( P_1 = (1 + \omega) (1 + \omega^2) = (- \omega^2) \times (- \omega) = 1 \)

\( P_ 2 = P_1 ( 1 + \omega^4)(1 + \omega^8) = P_1 ( 1 + \omega^3 . \omega)(1 + \omega^6 . \omega^2) = P_1 (1 + \omega)(1 + \omega^2) = P_1^2 \)

In general, \( P_n = (P_1)^n = 1^n = 1 \)

explanation_txt:
Let \(\cot ^{-1} x=\theta \, \, \Rightarrow \, \, x=\cot \theta \)

Now \(\text{cosec}\, \theta =\sqrt{1+\cot ^{2} \theta } =\sqrt{1+x^{2} } \)

\[{\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise4pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu} \, \, \, \sin \theta =\cfrac{1}{\text{cosec}\, \theta } =\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{1+x^{2} } } \]

\[\Rightarrow \, \theta =\sin ^{-1} \left( \cfrac{1}{\sqrt{1+x^{2} } }\right) \]

Hence \[ \sin \, (\cot ^{-1} x)\, =\sin \, \left(\sin ^{-1} \cfrac{1}{\sqrt{1+x^{2} } } \right)\] \[=\cfrac{1}{\sqrt{1+x^{2} } } =(1+x^{2} )^{-1/2} .\]

Plotting these lines, we obtain a graph:

The vertices of the rectangle are:

\( (1,0), (2,1), (-1,2), (0,3) \)

The area is:

quest_title: A rod of length '\(\text{l}\)' is rotated by a angle '\(\theta\) ' keeping its one end fixed then change in position vector of tip of rod will be.
explanation_txt:
\(|\overrightarrow{\mathrm{OA}}|=|\overrightarrow{\mathrm{OB}}|=1\)

\(\begin{aligned} \overrightarrow{\mathrm{AB}} &=\overrightarrow{\mathrm{OB}}-\overrightarrow{\mathrm{OA}} \\ \mathrm{AB} &=\sqrt{I^{2}-2 l^{2} \cos \theta+l^{2}} \\ &=\sqrt{2 l^{2}(1-\cos \theta)} \\ &=\sqrt{2 \mathrm{l}^{2} \times 2 \sin ^{2} \cfrac{\theta}{2}}=2 l \sin \cfrac{\theta}{2} \end{aligned}\)
question_plain_title: A rod of length '' is rotated by a angle ' ' keeping its one end fixed then change in position vector of tip of rod will be.
ans1_plain_text: sin
ans2_plain_text: 2sin
ans3_plain_text: 2sin
ans4_plain_text: 2cos

quest_title: A particle of mass \(\text{m}\) moves from rest under the action of constant force \(\text{F}\) which acts for \(\text{t}\) seconds. The average power attained is
explanation_txt:
\(F=m a\)
\(a=\cfrac{F}{m}\)

\(\therefore P=\cfrac{F \cdot s}{t}=\cfrac{F \cdot \cfrac{1}{2} a t^{2}}{t}=F \cdot \cfrac{F}{2 m} \cdot t=\cfrac{F^{2} t}{2 m}\)

explanation_txt:

\(\begin{array} { l } { m _ { 1 } + m _ { 2 } = \cfrac { b } { - 1 } = \tan \alpha + \tan \beta } \\ { \text { and } m _ { 1 } m _ { 2 } = \cfrac { a } { - 1 } = \tan \alpha \tan \beta } \end{array}\)

\(\tan ( \alpha + \beta ) = \cfrac { \tan \alpha + \tan \beta } { 1 - \tan \alpha \tan \beta } = \cfrac { - b } { 1 - ( - a ) } = \cfrac { - b } { ( 1 + a ) }\)

On squaring and subtracting (ii) from (i);

\( g ^ { 2 } - f ^ { 2 } = a ^ { 2 } - b ^ { 2 }\)

Hence the locus is \(x ^ { 2 } - y ^ { 2 } = a ^ { 2 } - b ^ { 2 }\)

quest_title: The radius of which of the following orbit is same as that of the first Bohr's orbit of hydrogen atom
explanation_txt:
\(r_{H} =0.529\cfrac{n^{2} }{z} Å\)

For hydrogen ; \(n=1\) and \(z=1\) therefore \[r_{H} =0.529Å\]

For \(Be^{3+} :\, Z=4\) and \(n=2\)

Therefore \[r_{Be^{3+} } =\cfrac{0.529\times 2^{2} }{4} =0.529Å.\]

Cathode:

quest_title: The area of triangle formed by the line \( y - 3x = 6 \) and co-ordinate axes is:
explanation_txt:
The line \(y - 3x = 6\) cuts X-axis at \( (-2,0) \) and Y-axis at \( (0,6) \). [Otained by putting \(y=0\) and \(x=0\) respectively]

So, the area is \( \int_{-2}^{0} (3x+6) dx = 6 \)

Or, the intercepts are \( a=-2, b=6 \)

Area \( = \cfrac{1}{2} |a||b| = 6 \)

quest_title: Which of the following represents the dimensions of Farad?
explanation_txt:
Farad is the SI derived unit of Capacitance (C).

\(C = \cfrac { Q } { V } = \cfrac { [ A T ] } { \left[ M L ^ { 2 } T ^ { - 3 } A ^ { - 1 } \right] } = \left[ M ^ { - 1 } L ^ { - 2 } T ^ { 4 } A ^ { 2 } \right]\)
question_plain_title: Which of the following represents the dimensions of Farad?
explanation_plain_text: Farad is the SI derived unit of Capacitance (C).

\(n = \cfrac { 360 } { 45 } - 1 = 7\)

quest_title: Equation of any normal to the parabola \(y ^ { 2 } = 4 a ( x - a )\) is:
ans3_txt: \( y = m ( x - a ) + \cfrac { a } { m } \)
explanation_txt:
The normal to parabola \( y^2 = 4aX \) is \( y = mX - 2am - am^3 \)

Put, \( X = x - a \), the normal to \( y^2 = 4a ( x-a) \) is \(y = m(x-a) - 2am - am^3 \)

OR

[Let the normal be \( y = mx + c .... (i) \)

which is normal to \( y^2 = 4ax - 4a^2 \) at \( (h,k) \)

Then, \( k = mh + c \Rightarrow c = k - mh .... (ii) \)

The tangent at \( (h,k) \) has slope given by differentiating the parabola, i.e \( 2a/k \).

So, \( k = 2am \)

As, \( k^2 = 4ah - 4a^2, h = am^2 + a \)

From (ii), putting values of h and k, \( c = 2am - am^3 - am \) and from (i), we get, \( y = m (x-a) - 2am - am^3 \) ]

\( i = \cos {\pi \over 2} + i \sin { \pi \over 2} \)

So, \( \sqrt {i} = \left[ \cos \cfrac { 1 } { 2 } \left( 2 n \pi + \cfrac { \pi } { 2 } \right) + i \sin \cfrac { 1 } { 2 } \left( 2 n \pi + \cfrac { \pi } { 2 } \right) \right] \) where \( n \in {0,1} \)

Putting n =0 and 1, we get two roots:

\( \pm \cfrac { 1 + i } { \sqrt { 2 } } \)

OR

Let \( z =x + iy \) be square root of \(i \).

So, \( x^2 - y^2 + 2xy i = i \)

Equating real and imaginary parts, \( x = \pm y \) and \( xy = 1/2 \).

But as \( xy \) is positive, \( x \ne -y \)

So, \( x = y \) Hence \( z = \pm \cfrac{1+i}{\sqrt 2} \)

quest_title: If \(y = x + \cfrac { 1 } { x } ,\) then
ans1_txt: \(x ^ { 2 } \cfrac { d y } { d x } + x y = 0\)
ans2_txt: \(x ^ { 2 } \cfrac { d y } { d x } + x y = 0\)
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array} { l } { y = x + \cfrac { 1 } { x } \Rightarrow \cfrac { d y } { d x } = 1 - \cfrac { 1 } { x ^ { 2 } } } \\ { \text { Therefore } x ^ { 2 } \cdot \cfrac { d y } { d x } - x y + 2 = x ^ { 2 } \left( 1 - \cfrac { 1 } { x ^ { 2 } } \right) - x \left( x + \cfrac { 1 } { x } \right) + 2 = 0 } \end{array}\)

quest_title: If the area under two curves \( y = f(x) \) and \(y = g(x) \) above \(X\) axis bounded by the ordinates \(x=-a\) and \(x=a\) are equal, then the function \(h(x) = f(x)-g(x)\) is probably :
explanation_txt:
We are given:

\[ \int_{-a}^{a} f(x) dx = \int_{-a}^{a} g(x) dx \]

\[ \Rightarrow \int_{-a}^{a} (f(x) - h(x)) dx = 0 \]

So, \(h(x)\) is probably an odd function. (not necessarily)

quest_title: A piece of copper and the other of germanium are cooled from the room temperature to 80 K, then which of the following would be a correct statement
ans3_txt: Resistance of copper increases while that of germanium decreases
ans4_txt: Resistance of copper decreases while that of germanium increases
explanation_txt: Resistance of conductors ( \(\text{Cu}\)) decreases with decrease in temperature while that of semi-conductors ( \(\text{Ge}\)) increases with decrease in temperature.
